brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a common issue in RESTful Web Services where a resource method is annotated with multiple HTTP method annotations such as @GET, @POST, @PUT, etc. This is considered a bad practice as it can lead to confusion and unexpected behavior.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'resource-method-multiple-http-method-annotations' checks all classes and their methods in the project. For each method, it counts the number of HTTP method annotations (@GET, @POST, @PUT). If a method has more than one such annotation, it asserts a failure and generates a message indicating the method and class with the issue.
PRE_model_validation: The rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, such as getClasses, getMethods, hasAnnotation, and getName. The rule logic is sound as it checks for multiple HTTP method annotations on a single method, which aligns with the rule's purpose.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. 'https://www.baeldung.com/jax-rs-annotations': This page provides a comprehensive guide to JAX-RS annotations, including HTTP method annotations. It emphasizes that each resource method should be annotated with exactly one HTTP method annotation.
2. 'https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25262765/jax-rs-multiple-http-methods-in-a-single-method': This StackOverflow discussion highlights the confusion and potential issues that can arise when a single resource method is annotated with multiple HTTP method annotations.
